### Discussion 3: [HIGH ENGAGEMENT] 

**Date:** 2025-12-05 22:48:51 | **Topic:** 15-networking-community
**Engagement:** 53 reactions, 120 comments
**Source:** https://www.facebook.com/groups/uncagedcliniciangroup/permalink/1915540072550549/

**Original Post:**
I've seen a lot of concern about us losing the title "professional". The absolute lowest bar of acting like a professional is being a member of your professional organization. 

APTA is all over this fight and other fights like it every day, year after year. They protect and maintain our profession from constant attacks on our scope and our payment. I hope you'll join the 100,000 members of APTA who choose to support these constant battles that threaten our profession.
 

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** I'm going to step away from this and let it bubble a little bit, but I'll be back with more responses. I would love to hear more from others who have had positive experiences in APTA. I see your thumbs up, but we need more vocal advocacy like this for our essential organization. Most people don't understand what a professional organization does, and I'm happy to try to pull back the curtain. A lot fo the work sounds boring, but it is literally the difference between PT existing and being swallowed up bit-by-bit by "body workers" and others. We would cease to exist shockingly fast without APTA.

> **Response 2:** All the pitchforks and torches came out to represent here, and I can't possibly find the time to respond to all of them. If you see that a bunch of people were clamoring for continued representaion as "professionals", and others could care less and have other priorities.... and then you multiply that by hundreds of issues with differing opinions across 300,000 licensed PTs, you start to see the complexity of APTA. I hope more of the PT profession can start to see APTA not as an optional organization, but one that fills hundreds of essential roles that no other organization can fill. Once we, as a profession, recognize that fact, we can all work together to make our profession and it's impact on people even better.

### Discussion 16: [HIGH ENGAGEMENT]

**Original Post:**
This post is for those who are nervous about networking with local businesses. I met with six different businesses over the last two weeks - two small gyms, a running shoe store, a massage therapist, and two Pilates studios. Of those six businesses and WITHOUT ME ASKING: 

- three offered to host a pop-up for me 
- one offered to host a workshop â€œbecause I have so many clients I know will benefit from thisâ€
- the shoe store wants me at local runs they organize as medical coverage â€œand so you can get free advertisingâ€
- one offered to rent me a room should I want a home base 
- two offered to feature my business as part of their monthly newsletters with their email lists
- one Pilates studio walked me down the street to introduce me to a local acupuncturist â€œbecause they need to know about your businessâ€ 

Will all of these pan out perfectly? No. But people are far more encouraging than I anticipated. All I did was:

1. Tell these businesses that I want to know where to send my clients (so their biz will benefit from meeting with me)
2. Speak about how I want to fill a need in my community that other PT clinics donâ€™t
3. I was honest in telling these businesses that I just started advertising my services and hope to make it a full time venture. 

Iâ€™ve reached out to about 20 businesses so far and I anticipate many wonâ€™t return my messages or be interested in meeting - and thatâ€™s okay! 

So many of you have been encouraging and I really appreciate this community â¤ï¸ I hope this can be a boost for others like me who dislike networking or have been intimidated by reaching out to local businesses.

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** Thatâ€™s awesome! What did that look like from the start?
-did you contact them ahead of time to schedule a meeting, or just drop in on them?
-who did you ask to speak with or meet with?
-what did you lead with as your first introduction? And how did you talk about your business?
-were these businesses that your friends/family already go to or own, or were these â€œcoldâ€ meetings?
-at what point did you offer to help them, and how did you word it?

> **Response 2:** For those asking, here is a cold email I sent to one of the gyms and feel free to steal:    Hi Gabe,

Iâ€™m happy to see a gym in Gig Harbor that focuses on well-rounded strength training for clients. I have a new business in Gig Harbor as a mobile physical therapist and am looking for the best places to send my patients to build strength and fitness during or after injury, or for my patients who are focusing on performance.

From your website, I get the sense that your business is geared towards a wide variety of people! Are there certain types of clients who benefit most from your services? Particular areas of interest for your trainers?

If possible, Iâ€™d love to come in and say hi or at least talk over the phone. This would allow me to better understand what you offer clients.

Pt referred to PT with order 2-3x/wk x 12 wksâ€¦..

Pt discharged less than 4 wks ago after couple months tx with max potential reachedâ€¦â€¦

PT eval concludes no skilled tx needed as no functional decline noted . (obviously pt is upset about it as they think PT is personal trainer from insurance) 

Now,
Question 1: does this make physician upset as well? 
Question 2: did PT do anything wrong? 
Question 3: how would you explain this to the pt as physician order specified the frequency and duration already?

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** PT determines frequency and duration, not the physician based on medical necessity. If the PT decides 1x/wk for 4 wks before DC or 3x/wk on 1st follower by 2x/wk on 2nd wk. It is up to the evaluating therapist. The physician will not protect you if insurance or Medicare determines that you are over utilizing or abuse of the services.

> **Response 2:** PT determines the frequency. It's their professional judgement and treatment plan. Writing frequency on a referral is old school. If the patient's goals are met, they are done. > **Response 1:** So let me make a distinction. There is a difference between opening your own practice (non compete), and taking their companyâ€™s resources (non solicitation). They can absolutely come after you for solicitation of their clients while an employee of their company. Clients are the $$ of a company. Iâ€™m 2 years into running my own mobile part B business and have kept busy schedule throughout this time, however the process of staying busy gets frustrating. I have 2 doctors offices, one social worker and a couple med A therapists who are main referral sources. It seems that unless Iâ€™m reaching out with a â€œhey if you have any patients who are in need of PT, I have immediate availabilityâ€, they donâ€™t refer. Feel like I constantly have to nudge and annoy these people, but it works so far. Iâ€™ve shown my appreciation by ordering lunch on numerous occasions. They all say they have patients in need of home PT, but yet donâ€™t reach outâ€¦ anyone else feel the same way/have the same struggles?

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** You have to realize that those offices see dozens of people like you walk in and out of their offices with luncheons, brochures, etc.  Whether it's from pharm reps, radiology reps, or PTs.  You have to stand out to make sure they think of you first when referring a patient to home PT.  Otherwise it's just another one of many free lunches from a "rep".  Get to know the front desk personnel..those are the people that actually hand the list of PTs to the patients.  I went so far as to offer PT to one of these front desk personnel that needed PT.  Once they see how you stand out from otherwise, they will tell patients to go to you when patients ask, "which PT on this list is the best?"

> **Response 2:** Word of mouth has worked best for me. No md. People tell others

**Original Post:**
ISOLATION: The second great killer of your business 

You weren't meant to do THIS alone and by "THIS" I don't just mean business. 

Scenario 1: I hate when people outside a select few friends ask me how business is going. It doesn't seem fair to have to communicate something as complicated as an entrepreneur's emotions. It's great, it's terrible, it's ok, it's frustrating, it's exhilarating, it's everything at the same time. So most of the time people ask I simply say "it's going well" and leave it at that. 

The problem with this? It puts you on an island feeling that no one can possibly understand or know what you're going through. 

Scenario 2: there's something that's been engrained in you from your childhood- using other people to help you is cheating, you need to do it on your own, group projects are awful, and if you collaborate with someone it cheapens what you're accomplishing. 

All of these things have gone through my head from time to time. I want to prove to everyone that I can do it on my own and don't need to rely on support or help from outsiders. "I didn't borrow money from a wealthy family member to get started." "I'm the reason people are coming to my practice." "I'm going to see how far I can get it on my own before asking for help." 

Phrases like this are so prevalent in our culture. 

Both of these scenarios create a pattern of isolation that make us susceptible to a number of problems. We burn out because we can't sustain the level of energy we're putting in. We quit because there's no accountability to push through challenges. We feel depressed because we're alone. 

At the very least you don't need to do this alone but the honest truth is that doing this alone is irresponsible. Don't let yourself become susceptible to isolation. Surround yourself with community to support you and allow you to have the greatest opportunity to have true success.

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** Good timing. Rough day!

> **Response 2:** Perfect timing for this!  Ty! 
Iâ€™m a bit tired of the island lately â¤ï¸

### Discussion 147: [HIGH ENGAGEMENT] 

**Date:** 2024-07-23 14:35:41 | **Topic:** 04-marketing-client-acquisition
**Engagement:** 4 reactions, 23 comments
**Source:** https://www.facebook.com/groups/uncagedcliniciangroup/permalink/1516568605781033/

**Original Post:**
This seems so basic, but how do you actually drop off marketing materials to referring clinicians/mds?

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** Something off beat or off the wall like a shock and awe package.
Having written a book on your expertise works well, because it takes up physical space on their desk or shelf, but stays subconsciously in the mind. 
Mail a package of peanuts directly to the doctor with a flyer saying â€œYouâ€™d be nuts not to work with usâ€
A rubber foot saying â€œIâ€™ve done the hard work for you and got my foot in the doorâ€¦now hereâ€™s how we can work with each other to benefit our patientsâ€
If you have a local podcast, getting them on as a guest then opening the 2 way street is a good one.

> **Response 2:** Here's my process (I'll probably get a million comments saying I'm doing it wrong but....). When I go in, I only bring one form of marketing materials, letter, brochure, card, so I have excuses to come back and drop off more. When I go in, I ask the front desk person their name and if I can drop off materials for the doctor (s). Always respect their level of busy-ness. If they have time for small chitter-chatter while I get out the materials, then that's fine. As soon as I leave the office, I write down the name of the front desk person and any little details they said (going on vacation soon, only work in the mornings, etc). I then put in my calendar when I'll be coming back to drop off more info. On the return visit, I say hello to the front desk person by name and say something about our last conversation (how was your vacation? I came in the morning because I knew you'd be here....) While dropping off different marketing materials from the last time, I try to get some Intel from the front desk (would I be able to schedule a meeting with the doc? How does your office handle PT referrals? Etc). It's a snowball process of getting the trust of the front desk, the gatekeepers. So you can get in to see the MDs face to face.

**Original Post:**
I am an OT and I am interested in starting a cash-based wellness business for adults (mostly 50+ based on demographics where I am). Not interested in dealing with insurance at all - so strictly focusing on wellness. Several years ago I had my own, small private mobile OT business and I am having trouble shifting my mindset! ðŸ¤¯

ðŸ’¡ Would love to hear about other wellness based businesses - what services/programs do you offer? 
ðŸ“š How do you highlight your OT/PT skills and knowledge while clearly indicating that you are not providing that skilled therapy? 

Example I encountered just in conversation about starting to see clients privately -  someone who is about 3 months post-stroke w lingering hemiparesis, living home independently.   This person would certainly benefit from skilled services  (postural alignment, quality of movement, strength)- how to you draw the line and what would make your services â€œwellnessâ€ vs OT/PT. 
â€¦ I can 100% agree with an argument that a very knowledgeable personal trainer could provide appropriate exercise for this patient. BUT - as a licensed OT, would I be crossing a line?

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** This is basically what my business is. Iâ€™m a PT, and my take on wellness is a) if someone could learn what Iâ€™m teaching in a weekend, itâ€™s not skilled and therefore not PT, and b) if thereâ€™s no specific diagnosis that Iâ€™m working on itâ€™s not PT. 

I like to say Iâ€™m doing personal training with a PTs eyes.

> **Response 2:** Think of recreation vs necessity. Medicare doesn't care if people can golf, play pickleball, etc for example. They want function: just get to the toilet, don't fall, etc. Your client wants to do more than basic function, so make it clear that in your practice that= wellness. Also clearly state on your website that you do not take insurance and that your "wellness" work is  to make the enjoyment of life better. Hope that helps. I struggled here too, but now am good with thinking wellness is anything over basic function. Good luck in the new practice.

### Discussion 191: [HIGH ENGAGEMENT] 

**Date:** 2023-12-12 16:56:16 | **Topic:** 04-marketing-client-acquisition
**Engagement:** 7 reactions, 18 comments

**Original Post:**
Does anyone have recommendations/advice on how to do better marketing? Specifically via social media/Instagram to gain folllowers?  I now have online fitness programs up on Everfit app and trying to find ideas on how to better market the programs and gain clients.  Marketing to my womens mountain bike club of 3,500+ ladies hasnâ€™t been enough so far.  ðŸ˜’

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** Be consistent, pool your audience to know what they want to know, create content around what they want to know and not what you think they want to know, be consistent and post daily.

> **Response 2:** Donâ€™t overcomplicate it. Just provide value. Post simple videos or text posts answering a common question or issue your clients run into. Do NOT get caught into the trap of trying over explain yourself in your caption (we all do it). Because then it will take you like 45 minutes to make 1 post. Keep things as simple as you can and try to make each post just 1 main thing you are trying to get across. Donâ€™t worry about editing posts or anything. Just post. Show your personality (people work with people they like). See what works and what doesnâ€™t. Go from there. 

Why would somebody want your program? What are they going to get out of it? And I donâ€™t mean â€œget stronger, more fit, etc etcâ€ because every program ever says that. What actual problem will your program help solve for mountain bikers? What are the things people complain about most often? Stay on the bike longer? No longer need long rest breaks once you get to the top? 

Donâ€™t try to just post stuff on the mountain biking group to market, just be in there a lot and answer questions and show them you are knowledgeable and eventually people will reach out to you. 

Think of social media marketing as farming. Just keep planting seeds, and then eventually youâ€™ll be able to harvest them.

### Discussion 215: [HIGH ENGAGEMENT] 

**Date:** 2025-12-09 17:14:41 | **Topic:** 04-marketing-client-acquisition
**Engagement:** 4 reactions, 17 comments
**Source:** https://www.facebook.com/groups/uncagedcliniciangroup/permalink/1918533988917824/

**Original Post:**
Iâ€™ve been connecting with a local DPC/concierge doc, and we want to formally collaborate. Sheâ€™d like to be able to pipeline her patients to me, but include my service as part of the fee theyâ€™re already paying her (so not just a referral, and then they pay for my service). We are trying to figure out how to make this work so that I am also getting paid what I am due. Could this be as simple as the physician paying me out of petty cash from her practice when I see one of her clients, or do we need to go through credenting and billing as if a traditional clinic? Or something else?? Open to ideas â€¦ I have been totally solo an fully cash-based practice for several years, so this is new territory!!

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** I love that youâ€™re thinking through this before you jump in, because the way you structure it now is whatâ€™s going to make this collaboration actually work long term.

There are a few clean ways to look at it.

First option: treat it like youâ€™re getting free leads. If she wants to keep her pricing exactly the same and not rearrange anything, that can still work. The big thing is you cannot let people just show up at your door expecting free ongoing PT. You need a 15 minute phone call with them first so you can set expectations clearlyâ€¦
â€œHereâ€™s what the eval normally costs, hereâ€™s what this first session looks like inside your DPC membership, and hereâ€™s what people with your issue typically need in terms of sessions.â€
Basically give it the full discovery call feel so they understand where the free part ends and where your actual plan of care begins. That protects you and makes the whole thing way smoother.

Second option: if sheâ€™s planning to raise her prices, then your service can just be baked into that increase. It becomes a value add for her members and she stays whole financially. My guess is sheâ€™s probably not looking to raise prices, but itâ€™s still worth mentioning because itâ€™s the most straightforward version of the model.

Third option: she pays you directly per person she sends over. If you go this route, compare it to what youâ€™d normally spend on acquiring a patient. If youâ€™re running paid ads, depending on your city you might be paying anywhere from $80 to $150 just to get someone on a phone call. These arenâ€™t cold traffic leads though. These are warm, already-sold referrals coming from someone they trust. Thatâ€™s worth a lot. Your conversion rate on those will typically be double what you get from ads.

If you frame it that way, you can structure a win-win so every patient who needs PT goes straight to you as the default, not â€œone of several options.â€ She sells it as part of the experience. You take it from the first call onward.

So youâ€™ve got a few models here. Just make sure whatever you choose sets expectations properly and positions you as the consistent PT solution for her people. Thatâ€™s where this kind of relationship becomes genuinely fruitful instead of chaotic.

> **Response 2:** You have to be careful with these laws -the easiest way is to just accept referrals from the doc : 

Federal Anti-Kickback Statute (AKS): Prohibits knowingly offering, paying, soliciting, or receiving any remuneration (cash, gifts, discounts) to induce referrals for services paid by federal programs (Medicare/Medicaid).
Violations are felonies with severe penalties (prison, fines, exclusion from programs).
Stark Law (Physician Self-Referral Law): Prohibits physicians from referring patients for certain services (like lab work, PT, imaging) to entities they or their family have a financial relationship with (ownership or compensation), unless an exception applies.
State Laws: Many states (e.g., Texas) have independent anti-solicitation or anti-kickback laws that can be stricter.
Professional Ethics: The APA and other  organizations specify that payments should be for services rendered, not based on the referral.

I'm a physical therapist looking to connect with others who have partnered with gyms. I'm interested in learning more about how these relationships work, especially in regards to using gym equipment and bringing in non-member clients.

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** I do not have a private practice but have been researching here and there for a few years. These are great questions, but unfortunately, the answer is not one-size-fits-all. In terms of amenities and business practices, things may differ between gyms, so itâ€™s essential to know what you want for both your patients and your business.

Not allowing non-members would be a major red flag. Everything else can and should be negotiated.

If they want member priority, this could be harmful for growth, but you can counter with offering designated member-only times, discounted member rates, asking for lower rent, or requesting marketing support.

There is so much ambiguity in this aspect that it will be beneficial to know where you will excel and where you may struggle, so that you ensure the partnership is mutually beneficial and unlikely to lead to future tension.

Protect your brand and your values (this is your motivation and drive), ensure a contract is formed (with plenty of reflection and revision), have an exit strategy in writing, and build in a re-negotiation date at a certain checkpoint.

As for structure, the most common that you will see are flat rate rent, percentage of revenue, or a hybrid. If you expect very fast growth, then a flat rate may be optimal. If you expect slow growth, a percentage of revenue may be better. A hybrid offers them a guarantee while giving you protection if growth is slow.

You could offer a revenue cap where you pay a percentage of revenue up to a certain threshold, followed by a reduction in percentage â€” possibly even to zero. Another option is a tiered split, where the percentage decreases as your revenue increases.

> **Response 2:** Depends on your agreement/contract with gym. I like percent per visit (can be anywhere 10-30% depending on how everything is set up) rather than flat fee, this gives the gym incentive to send people your way.

### Discussion 262: [HIGH ENGAGEMENT] 

**Date:** 2025-05-01 13:51:09 | **Topic:** 04-marketing-client-acquisition
**Engagement:** 1 reactions, 16 comments
**Source:** https://www.facebook.com/groups/uncagedcliniciangroup/permalink/1730941781010380/

**Original Post:**
Hi everyone
Iâ€™m checking UHC insurance benefits and I always get confused when it says no referral required and no visit limits. Does it mean I can see patient without a doctorâ€™s referral , no signed POC and however long the patient needs? Insurance also says do not charge $35 co-pay. Sheâ€™s a neuro patient . Please advise, I am not trying to beat the system, I just need guidance because Iâ€™m new to this. Thank you

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** Typically then you'd follow your state practice act. Always follow the strictest rule

> **Response 2:** Q: Checking insurance benefits and I always get confused when it says no referral required, and no visit limits. 
Can I see the patient without a doctorâ€™s referral, no signed POC and however long the patient needs? 

No referral means it's not an HMO plan that would need a referral. 
Check your state direct access laws, we have 20 days or 10 visits whichever is sooner without a script, and a script from a doctor is needed to have the insurance pick it up. And also charts need a doctor's signed POC/eval and re-evals.
You have to be able to show progress, and it be a skilled therapy needed and not maintenance care. Otherwise if there's a plateau (after one re-eval already having a flare up) they may try their HEP on their own a bit, because insurance may reject payment and the bill may fall to the patient.
Also unlimited visits may also have a money cap if it's Medicare, which is about 30 visits before the chart would be audited and modifiers need to be added each time. 
Was told some neuro can be tough because can be auto immune dx e.g. M.S. where it does not always steadily improve. But working in Ortho, I don't have all the insurance and outs.

**Original Post:**
Hi everyone,

So I know we can't offer financial incentives for referrals due to kickback laws. 

I know some people who "get around" this by donating to charity. ie. "I can't offer direct financial compensation for referrals but I'd be happy to donate $50 to a charity of your choice for each referral"
 
What're people's thoughts? Genius or straight up illegal?

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** Straight curious: If you're outside insurance (and especially CMS stuff) do the anti-kickbacks even apply? Those are federal regs for federal programs, right? I've never seen a state practice act address anything like this.

> **Response 2:** Eric Schneider David Bayliff

Hey I understand the sentiment guys and the value of building relationships. But I don't see why you couldn't employ both if it is legal? They aren't mutually exclusive tactics. 

For example, massage therapists offer referral discounts all the time, since they aren't subject to healthcare kickbacks. They see a client for X number of sessions. After they've built trust with the client they ask them to recommend their services to people they know and say "I offer a $20 gift voucher for any referrals that come in" This happens in gyms and other wellness businesses too. 

It happens even more often in non health/wellness businesses. Does that mean building relationships isn't important in their industries just because they use financial incentives? I would argue no. 

Regardless, I just thought it was an interesting idea. I'm not going to employ it as of yet but I don't want to completely discredit it either. I definitely don't want to if it isn't legal. Can anyone comment on legality?

**Original Post:**
I have created a policy for my clinic that, when a law firm reaches out for client records, I contact the client, and then email them the records, telling them they are welcome to forward/share as they see appropriate.  
I tell the law firm (without confirming who is and isn't a client) that all clients have access to their records and can share with them if they would like to.  

(all of our clients do have access to their records anytime via the online portal, but I send them all in 1 PDF for ease and as a courtesy.)

I just had a large law firm tell me that this is unheard of and be very frusterated during the hour that it took for the client to forward them their records.

Am I missing something?  Does anyone else just provide the records directly to clients?

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** Usually the records come with something signed by the patient allowing them to request them and for you to send. However- I invoice the law firm and will not send until they pay us for them.

> **Response 2:** ï¿¼You are the custodian of those records, legally. Simply sending a copy of records to a patient does not relinquish your custodial responsibility of protected health information.

If a third-party ï¿¼entity has a record request with a signed patient consent form we have a legal requirement to send those records, but like some have referenced already, in certain situations we can invoice and withhold record delivery until that invoice is paid. ï¿¼ this tends to vary depending on area jurisdiction. ï¿¼

A clinic policy like you have described does not supersede or replace ï¿¼custodial responsibility. There is a very specific process you have to go through to transfer that custodial responsibility. ï¿¼

### Discussion 348: [HIGH ENGAGEMENT] 

**Date:** 2022-07-19 15:11:30 | **Topic:** 15-networking-community
**Engagement:** 26 reactions, 0 comments
**Source:** https://www.facebook.com/groups/uncagedcliniciangroup/permalink/1013632806074618/

**Original Post:**
We just got back from rafting the Grand Canyon and I had one of the most resonating experiences I've had in a very long time. Spilling my guts here but I think this group will appreciate the sentiment as well as anyone. 

When I was in college, I had the amazing fortune of working as a river guide for 5 years on the Colorado River, mostly in the Grand Canyon. That job prepared me for working as a PT and especially as a small business owner better than almost any other life experience. 

Rafting the Grand Canyon requires traversing a nearly 300 mile long stretch of river that includes some of the biggest whitewater in North America. We use these huge 37 foot, 4 ton, motorized rafts that can carry up to 20 people at a time. 

I applied for my permit to do this in 1997(!), which was the last year I guided and when I was first starting PT school. It's safe to say that I was going into this a bit rusty because there I was, 25 years later, piloting one of those huge motorized rafts, carrying 16 of my family and friends for 10 days, through historically low water.

As intimidated as I was going into this, one of the best things was how awesome it was to  F E E L the Support and Camaraderie from the other boaters down there, both private and commercial. Mistakes are going to happen and we need each other. Everyone has to camp somewhere at night and we have to unofficially coordinate who is staying where. 

The private trips were smaller and scattered around, most of them hadn't really done it before. The big commercial outfitters were pushing through with their huge groups, either in their motor rigs or with groups of up to 6 smaller rafts. But everyone is a part of the community. Everyone has to work together.

That feeling of support and camaraderie I felt in the Grand Canyon is extremely similar to what I feel in this user group. 
It's the feeling I get when I work with other practice owners who are trying to make their way. 
It's the feeling I get when I volunteer with the Private Practice Section of the APTA. 
And it's the feeling I get when I volunteer for our Home Health and Hospice Association or our local Climbing Advocacy Group.

With so many people running through the Grand Canyon at any given time, things could be a lot more competitive. Fortunately, it was absolutely refreshing and impressive to be a part of a community in which the guides and boatmen from each company and private trip work together to look out for each other. This was true for helping each other through the low water runs as well as for coordinating who was camping where each night.

I'd never seen water that low. Somehow, at every turn, another boatman had my back. This stuff is not easy. 
It's very technical. 
Sometimes it's extremely hot. 
Sometimes there are storms that bring thundering flash floods. 
Sometimes other people get stuck on the rocks and we have to help pull them off.

All of that feels extremely similar when I have random employment questions or regulatory or billing questions. The other 'guides' on our trip are incredibly positive as they rally with each other so we all get down safely.

There is an amazing community experience down in the Grand Canyon! There are also amazing communities here in Uncaged, with the Private Practice Section and with the other associations we have out there.  

Thanks to everyone for looking out for each other! What a cool thing to be a part of!

**Original Post:**
I'm sure this group will relate, but I recently realized I am not providing the quality patient care I would like to because of all the flaming hoops insurance has put up. I am going to make the jump to cash based and have a question for the group. 

I am in a pretty small town so I will likely need a side job as I get started. I am a physical therapist with over 15 years of outpatient experience in orthopedics and pelvic health. I am fairly certain my current employer will not be willing to let me gradually transition out. I am not picky, it doesn't have to be PT related or even in the medical/fitness field. Any suggestions?

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** Itâ€™s a little different animal going cash based and Iâ€™ve found the expectations are more like a trainer (I want this, this and this) than in insurance world because they are putting their own money up.  If you can fill in the gaps getting some fitness world exposure that would be helpful because for a lot of patients that is the choice they are making with their dollar (trainer vs. PT)

> **Response 2:** Small isolated town could work in your favor. Word of mouth will be a strong potential for referral. But if socioeconomics are not appropriate you will have more difficulty. Explaining difference between insurance based and private access is critical. Let patients know in many cases they are already paying for the bulk of the cost. Explain as private pay you time with them is devoted to them not paperwork for insurance company. Explain the process of reimbursement and authorizations and how that limits outpatient therapists ability to treat within full scope and autonomy. Not everyone will be interested but those that are will be. Need to show what the benefits will be to them. IE faster appointment scheduling, coming to their home or place of work, potentially fewer sessions needed, no waiting for authorizations, referrals, additional visits. Building a whole body wellness mindset starting with a relationship with a provider who can screen and make recommendations how they can feel better, be healthierâ€¦Your business model will reflect what those benefits are to the patients.

**Original Post:**
To those providers that live in Florida, I am a cash only PT and need to know what are the laws concerning Wellness sessions? 

How is Wellness defined in Florida?

Do we need a physician to sign off on the POC after 30 days as we do with direct access? 

How many sessions are allowed? 

What ICD 10 codes are used?

Do we need short and long term goals?

Please add any other relevant information.

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** No physician sign off required, no POC required, no minimum days it's based on what you and your client want. No ICD 10 codes required.

We should be utilizing short and long-term goals. Even good personal trainers do that. I also write up an assessment. Even if you look at some of the assessments in the personal training space, they are quite thorough. I look at joint mobility, ROM, lumbopelvic stability, screen for pelvic health issues, and assess functional movements and balance. And I write it all up just like I would for a PT assessment. Well actually I dictate it using Google docs, it's pretty fast. 

For the regular sessions for most of my training clients, I use a spreadsheet on a clipboard. It also contains an area for the assessment and plan and anything they may have told me that session. Essentially a spreadsheet soap note format.

> **Response 2:** Wellness and cash based PT are 2 different things completely. 
If you are training someone (which is essentially wellness), itâ€™s not function based and itâ€™s not diagnosis based.  Itâ€™s instead generalized mobility and strengthening.  Itâ€™s not sit<>stand function, itâ€™s â€œsquatsâ€, etc. 
Itâ€™s a mindset shift.  Notes are minimal and basically are non assessment check lists of the exercises performed.  

â€¢No MD signatures. 
â€¢No ICD codes 
â€¢As many sessions as you want. 
â€¢No goals needed unless you want some fitness threshold goals. 
â€¢depends on â€œclientâ€ demographic too. 

Think I got a little  wordy/redundant, but hopefully some clarification in there somewhere ðŸ˜†

### Discussion 440: [MEDIUM ENGAGEMENT] 

**Date:** 2023-12-14 04:01:55 | **Topic:** 04-marketing-client-acquisition
**Engagement:** 2 reactions, 9 comments
**Source:** https://www.facebook.com/groups/uncagedcliniciangroup/permalink/1372625210175374/

**Original Post:**
Anyone have any suggestions on marketing ideas? I'm supposed to open a prenatal/postpartum group fitness and physical therapy studio Evolution Mom NJ  in January and I've gotten a decent amount of traffic to my website but no bites yet, that is just with local doc visits (haven't gotten past the front desk)using social media and a local daycare email list. I've been doing what I can to boost my Google ranking but it's hard since I'm not technically open yet! 

I'm wondering if it's just bc I'm not open till Jan but was hoping to have had some inquiries/class registrations...

also not sure how to grow the local social media following? 

Any ideas!? 

Thanks in advance! This group has been so helpful in getting to this point!

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** One idea could be doing a workshop at a local library or other venue to give people a chance to get to know you and the specific problems you solve. 

Maybe even a free class at the end of the workshop to let people experience the services you offer.

> **Response 2:** Congrats! I def agree with the above, find some mom groups online and offline, offer a free workshop or class, and get to know your local midwives and doulas. 
For the website, which is beautiful btw, you may want to change a few things on your site structure. It's difficult to tell that you need to register or purchase classes on site from the homepage and from the schedule page. Also, instead of registering for a class it just adds it to the cart which can be confusing for people if not explained. Try updating that and adding more calls to action on the homepage so people have more direction. You can break up the longer paragraphs so only 1-2 sentences are together so it reads easier. 
As far as SEO, the site is missing important meta data, image alt text, the H1-H4 headers aren't appropriate, and try optimizing for local keywords. That should help your local search a lot, although Google can take up to 6 mo to show a site in search, you can manually submit the sitemap to speed that up.
Don't forget you need a popup for cookie approval to be compliant and a website privacy policy (you have HIPAA but you need a website one also or you can combine the two on one page). Just pick one social to concentrate on, you can always share the same things across tt, fb, and insta too.

Hi again,
Anyone have a template of email that they use to ask for Google Review?
Specific context: I am independent contractor in a clinic that does a lot or perinatal physiotherapy. I treat ortho and pelvic health of all genders. My colleague specializes in perinatal and does labour and delivery prep and post partum recovery. When we discharge a client, the admin says something like "would you consider leaving us a review?". and if they client says no problem, they get an email with reminder/link.
Almost all her clients leave her reviews but barely any leave for me. I am not sure if its because of the wording of the email. Or the fact that her patients don't (come for and therefore dont do rehab that is to ) heal from pain and dysfunction. , so they just mention that it was great experience etc. Whereas with me, they come with a problem and they get better and maybe they had expectations to be quicker or something so by the time they disharge, they arent as satisfied? not sure if its my imposter syndrome. So basically, any thoughts?
or templates?
Id like to build up my name there but if the reviews only mention my colleague. I also want people of all genders to know they are welcome but if you only see pregnancy reviews, can throw people off...
if you read until now, Thanks so much!

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** Have your clinic ask them after they've seen you for a few sessions and you've built rapport and starting to see progress.  No need to wait to DC, and oftentimes by that point they've already "moved on" and it's hard/ uncomfortable to hound them to write it. 

When I email my pts asking them about leaving a review I start with something like "it's been such a pleasure working with you and I'm so glad  you reported you can now lift your toddler painfree and run 2 miles without leaking, what great improvements! Id love to be able to help  other moms (insert population here) like you get the help they need. Would you be willing to leave a review so they know help is out there?" If they agree, I give them a guideline like:  "please include
why you sought PT, what issues were you dealing with and what functional limitations did you have, what has changed/ improved since you started?" 

Don't secondguess your skills! You know you can help them and you see them improving on the daily- own it!!

> **Response 2:** Why donâ€™t you ask them personally? Start with clients you feel really comfortable with and work from there. Iâ€™m an independent contractor for a mobile practice so there is no admin to do this for us!

> **Response 1:** I think itâ€™s important to understand that the largest payoff one could have from a workshop is clients signing up. Anyone have any good advice/tips for making posts to local community Facebook pages? I'm looking to take my Mobile Med B side hustle to full time, trying to get more community outreach. **Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** Local groups are great for building "famousity"! So be present in the groups. A lot.

Respond to people's posts, even if it has nothing to do with you.

Recommend services that you don't offer, but trust and feel confident recommending.

Connect with the other regular posters who share part of your vision; become their friend.

Pay attention to the most frequently asked questions that are relevant to you -- the questions can become content for you (digital or workshops or both), and the people asking can become people you offer free resources and information to, until they're ready to have you solve a problem they have.

If there's a "small business posting" day, use it.

If there are networking events advertised, try them.

I have been treating a patient post MVA. The daughter of the patient was unfortunately recently involved in a separate car accident. Recently a gym offered me the option of leasing space from them, but in hopes I would be able to offer PT. I can figure out the logistics- I have the LLC. ### Discussion 645: [MEDIUM ENGAGEMENT] 

**Date:** 2022-08-26 00:08:16 | **Topic:** 04-marketing-client-acquisition
**Engagement:** 0 reactions, 6 comments
**Source:** https://www.facebook.com/groups/uncagedcliniciangroup/permalink/1040148843423014/

**Original Post:**
What should I expect to pay for rent? 
I'm in a 300 sq. ft. space inside a CrossFit-style (not CF branded) gym. I'm good friends with the guy that owns the building and the gym, and he has let me build out the space and get my cash business started rent free thus far. He approached me tonight about starting to pay rent, but left the amount up to me. Obviously as a business owner, I want to tell him $1/month (ha!), but he's a good friend and is also a great referral source, as he's pretty popular in our small town, so I want to come up with a fair price. 
Pros:
Free utilities, internet
Gym has almost zero attendance until a bout 5pm everyday
Access to lots of general gym/workout equipment 

Cons:
Location on a side street, no frontage on a main road
Limited signage
Front door is always locked and gym members have a swipe card 
Gym area has only limited climate control (I do have AC/heat in my clinic area)
The owner does not make a profit off the gym, and prefers to keep membership low. It's basically his large friend group, so there isn't a substantial built-in referral base. 

For those who rent space in a gym, or sublease space in any other facility, what would a 300sq ft room cost? For reference, this is a relatively low income town and low cost of living area.

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** Whatever you decide do research and find an average. Present him the research/average and round up to a nice number. He deserves that respect.

Example: average for your square foot is $429/month. I'd round up to $475 or $500 per month. Don't round up too much but whatever you think is enough for him to feel appreciated

> **Response 2:** You could start out offering him a percentage like 25 percent of each visit not to exceed a certain total amount per month.That may work while still building and that way your not stressed about always coming up with that set amount each month.

**Original Post:**
I rent space out of a gym currently for my PT practice and specialize in working with athletes. Referrals from in house have been steady, but not enough to keep my schedule full. (Itâ€™s a small private gym.) 

No surprise that while other gyms and fitness facilities donâ€™t offer PT in house, referring clients to me because I am located in a gym is a barrier. 

Any advice on how to best approach outside trainers or gym facilities in this situation?

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** Gyms are territorial. 
It's easiest when they've been your patients and "get it" or get the type of client you are looking for.
Like anything these relationships take time to nurture, and knowing how much energy to put into the "right" relationships. It's like dating, they won't say yes on the first date. Keep showing up if you think it's worth the energy.

> **Response 2:** I was located in a CrossFit gym, and got referrals from all the other CrossFit gyms. For me it came down to knowing the individual trainers/coaches at the gyms, not the owners. Owners will be overprotective of their business (which is probably hurting them). The trainers and coaches will just do whatever they need to, to help their clients. 

If you have contact with the owners, you just need to make sure they know that your goal is to get their members healthy and back into their own gyms as quickly as you can so they donâ€™t cancel their memberships or feel like they are wasting them.

### Discussion 697: [MEDIUM ENGAGEMENT] 

**Date:** 2024-06-09 17:40:56 | **Topic:** 04-marketing-client-acquisition
**Engagement:** 0 reactions, 5 comments
**Source:** https://www.facebook.com/groups/uncagedcliniciangroup/permalink/1487631882008039/

**Original Post:**
does anyone use Google ads ? 
have they helped?

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** Google Ads can be a massive help, but results vary based on clinic type, your market, your website and ad budget.

Are you cash or insurance? Hybrid? What patient population are your targeting?

For instance, I've seen a TON of ad spend wasted on a small Google Ads budget in an area with little search volume. Targeting cash pay patients with a limited Google ads budget is difficult because a small budget means limited keywords to bid on, which means you're only targeting the highest buyer intent keywords and the vast majority of those keyword searches are coming form people who were referred to physical therapy and want to use their insurance and already have their minds made up.

If you need a quick and more predictable turn around personally I've found Facebook ads to be the fastest because you're reaching a much larger bucket of prospects because it doesn't require them to make a search before starting the conversation. $500 budget won't get you very far though.

If all I had was $500/mo to spend, I'd spend it on building and nurturing local relationships, and invest in ads when I'm ready to view it as an investment I want to scale vs a static number that I'm willing to light on fire every month.

**Original Post:**
Advice appreciated cause I donâ€™t know who to ask! This group is an absolute blessing.â€¦ 

Background info first:
Iâ€™m a DPT, CSCS with an LLC. 
Main gig is independent contractor at an ortho clinic and then I see private clients/athletes under my LLC with home visits. 

I also work for a gym 0-10 hours/week. Clients see me for personal training, recovery sessions, and physical therapy. The gym pays me as their highest level trainer. I do not operate out of the gym as my business, they pay me W2. Clients pay the gym, gym pays me as employee. So this is where all my questions come from with this setup. 

Most important question:
- I offer my home visit LLC clients a superbill obviously since that is my business but a gym client is asking, I said no since she pays the gym and not me (my personal info & medical credentials is not on her bills, she pays for a level X trainer). Is this the right assumption? Is there a better explanation to give her? I said, â€œI donâ€™t think so but Iâ€™ll do some research.â€ They then asked/suggested if I could write a letter with my info, medical reasons they are being seen and attach a gym billâ€¦ Iâ€™m not sure how to proceed     ðŸ™ any advice?ðŸ™ 

Two other questions if anyone has read this far: 
- Trainers want me to assess their Medicare age clients for minor injuries, HEP, and program advice/modifications. The goals are for in the gym & wellness is not covered by Medicare. Even so do I need to have them sign something strictly because they are consulting with a PT and no cash PT with Medicare eligible? Or should i just be extra clear in my personal documenting?

Consent form:
- I assume Iâ€™m covered by the gym since Iâ€™m hired as a trainer but they donâ€™t have anything to help regarding my license (Iâ€™m assuming). Because of this should I have those seeing me because Iâ€™m a PT sign a consent from my LLC? I have liability insurance under my LLC with the gyms name in the policy. Would a form even be valid in case something happened since the client never paid the LLC but only the gym?

In order to be a business you must act like a business but this pay setup makes that quite confusing ðŸ« . This is my fun job that Iâ€™m using to learn from, itâ€™s not permanent but Iâ€™d rather not give it up because having a PT license is over complicating it lol

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** I would not provide the gym client a superbill. You are seeing her as a trainer, not a PT. Though you are held to your highest license, if you start providing superbills at the gym you are essentially saying you are performing PT services which is not the intended job there and could get very muddy. If she wants to see you for reimbursable services she would have to see you through your LLC, in my opinion. Please note that all of this is just how I would operate things and is not intended as legal advice. Hope that helps.

> **Response 2:** If a gym client wants Physical Therapy give her option of home based or office based treatments not at the gym. Jumping back and forth as a trainer the a PT doing injury assessments and education is creating confusion for you so imagine how confused clients and patients will be. As far as liability in the event something happens and a law suit is filed typically Everyone gets pulled into the suit. Who ever pays the premium is the sole responsibility of that insurance company. Always protect yourself with your own policies even if employers has a policy with your name on it also.

**Engagement:** 2 reactions, 2 comments

**Original Post:**
What do you use to run demographic information to determine your new clinic location? Is there a way to find out about percentage of Medicare patients?

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** Unless you are planning on opening a Costco size clinic I wouldnâ€™t worry about those numbers too much. 

Are you looking at leasing an existing space or building a new space?

If leasing your options will be limited to what is available. 

When we opened new clinic locations we looked for ample parking near our front entrance, high visibility, easy exit from the parking lot, and we wanted the right neighbors. 

I liked opening in areas with hospital outpatient clinics or corporate clinics across the street or within view. We pick up a lot of new patients off their marketing and their waitlist. 

I would rather pay $1,000 more on rent and save $3,000 on ads because we are in a highly visible location.

> **Response 2:** Anthony Maritato brings up very good points.  Going into a "low traffic area" because MC clients are close by doesn't equate to them coming to you.  Use the benefit of other facilities being close by to help you!  That is why you see many clinics close to hospitals or even close to other clinics.  Gyms position themselves close to other gyms all the time, in part, for this reason.  Same with food chains

### Discussion 875: 

**Date:** 2024-08-30 19:59:20 | **Topic:** 15-networking-community
**Engagement:** 0 reactions, 3 comments
**Source:** https://www.facebook.com/groups/uncagedcliniciangroup/permalink/1542535986517628/

**Original Post:**
What are your top 2 interview questions when hiring a virtual assistant to make sure they are a good fit for your practice?

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** Did you see the list in the drive?

> **Response 2:** Organization is key. I have them tell me specifics about how they stay organized. I will often give them a task as a test (paid for) and we'll use that to assess them.  It is usually a task that takes a good amount of organization. If they are also going to be customer facing and communicating with customers on a regular basis then I also test their their communication skills. Often I will give them a scenario and ask them to respond to a patient. It will be fake, but it lets me test what their email/phone skills are like and how they communicate and how they come off.  It also allows me to test how they do with problem solving given limited instructions.  These tasks are also timed tasks so it lets me assess their ability to meet deadlines.

Hi , I am a new start up clinic based in CA . I am looking for resources to manage direct access patients. I was wondering ,

2 . Tips to ensure I receive signed POC in timely manner . Having trouble navigating through this .

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** Medicare doesn't really care about scripts. But direct access or not, a claim must have a referring provider. This is who will sign the POC. Some clinics require a script to ensure this doctor will sign. But if audited, Medicare wants to see a signed POC. Not a script.

> **Response 2:** Curious, are you not familiar with your Practice Act, is that why you are asking someone to post a link?  Just respectfully curious??

- notify the patients that they can be seen for 12 sessions or 45 days, whichever comes first, after which we need a signed plan of care
- notify the treating physician that the patient is receiving care (requiring the signed written consent from the patient to reach out to their physician)
- and, if beyond the 45 day / 12 visit limit, get a signed and dated plan of care 

As a one-man show the prospect of having to track down PCPs to sign plans of care for patients seems like it's going to add a lot of admin time.

* Do all practices really do this - specifically the notices? I've been to a PT before myself and I don't recall getting notified of this, though I'm sure there was stuff on the back end I didn't see
* What qualifies as "wellness"? Because wellness visits don't seem to fall under this requirement, what differentiates a wellness visit from normal PT?
* I know a lot of folks don't have established PCPs. Is there any way around this requirement for a signed plan of care if the patient doesn't have an MD etc available to evaluate them?

Thanks for any advice

PSA....  Phishing scam alert: 
I have had 2 in the last few months. This morning I got an email supposedly from my independent contractor who I pay direct deposit through quickbooks. Posed as her saying that she had changed her deposit bank account and needed to know how to update that for all future payments. It was obviously not her email and the wording was very generic.
A few months ago I received one from a "French PT" who had a client visiting the area for the summer and wanted to know if I could see their patient for back pain a few times/week. This would not be super unusual because I am in a resort area. They even took a bunch of descriptors from my website and included them to sound legit. I pointed them to my online booking site and then they replied asking if I would take a check from the person's manager and refund whatever funds I did not need.
I am a super small business and am frankly surprised that they found me and are putting energy into it. If they are finding me - they can find you (if you have a business website). Stay alert.
